qas.question: Who was Thomas Muntzer never able to become?
Which Thuringian district did the Roman Catholic faith die in?

context: Thuringia generally accepted the Protestant Reformation, and Roman Catholicism was suppressed <a0_0><b5_0>as early as 1520<b5_0/><a0_0/>[citation needed]; priests who remained loyal to it <a1_0><b6_0>were driven away<b6_0/><a1_0/> and churches and monasteries were largely destroyed, especially <a2_0><b7_0>during the German Peasants' War of 1525<b7_0/><a2_0/>. In Mühlhausen and elsewhere, the Anabaptists found many adherents. Thomas Müntzer, <a3_0><b8_0>a leader of some non-peaceful groups<b8_0/><a3_0/> of this sect, was active in this city. Within the borders of modern Thuringia the Roman Catholic faith only survived in <a4_0><b9_0>the Eichsfeld district<b9_0/><a4_0/>, which was ruled by the Archbishop of Mainz, and to a small degree in Erfurt and its immediate vicinity.
